abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Private Tubewell
            Development Project for Pakistan was unsatisfactory due to a
            low ERR (Economic Rate of Return). The project achieved most
            of its objectives, sustainability is likely, and the
            performance of both the Bank and Borrower was satisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            reliable data is essential at the design stage. Second,
            realistic forecasts of critical input prices, including
            diesel oil and electricity, should be made during project
            preparation. Third, there should be mechanisms at the
            project level to continuously monitor and report changes in
            economic conditions surrounding projects. Fourth, irrigation
            projects involving farmer participation should have
            provisions for promoting social organization/community
            development, preferably through the inputs of
            sociologists/anthropologists with the required expertise.
            Fifth, future groundwater development projects should have a
            built-in component for developing a regulatory framework to
            ensure sustainability. Finally, in Pakistan, the Bank should
            ensure consistency of the PC-1 with the SAR and legal documents.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Private Tubewell Development
            Project, located in one of the least developed areas of
            Punjab province, is the first Government effort to
            facilitate the development of new fresh groundwater areas
            through intensive private tubewell (TW) installation. The
            project is designed to test the viability of an integrated
            private TW development program for increasing agricultural
            production. To achieve this objective, the project consists
            of: (i) a complete distribution network to extend
            electricity to about 8,000 tubewells, and infrastructure for
            the electrification of about 200 villages and 300
            agroindustry units; (ii) improvement to watercourses; (iii)
            technical assistance to ensure adequate back-up for the
            implementing agencies and to provide training for the
            project staff; and (iv) engineering and office equipment.
            The installation of TWs will be financed by farmers by
            availing of funds from an ongoing agricultural credit program.

            Project, located in one of the least developed areas of

            facilitate the development of new fresh groundwater areas
